title: About
text:
This website was created as a project for the course “DS 002R: Foundations of Data Science, R” at Pomona College.
In the Tab “Data Visualization”, there are two visualizations created using R, with data sourced from the TidyTuesday data repository. The TidyTuesday Project is a collection of data frames, released every week from 2018 to present day. The data collected in these frames are endless, with data quantifying Olympic Medals to data describing Himalayan Climbers. The project is open to anyone and everyone, and it aims to provide opportunities for individuals to learn how to work with real-world data sets through data science.

title: Coffee Survey
text:
library(tidytuesdayR)
library(tidyverse)

# imports data from tidytuesday
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2024, week = 20)

# renames data
coffee_survey <- tuesdata$coffee_survey

# removes NAs from variables age and favorite
cleaned_coffee_survey <- coffee_survey |>
  filter(!is.na(age) & !is.na(favorite))

# creates a new data frame with age and favorite, counts the occurences of each favorite per age group
data_summary <- cleaned_coffee_survey |>
  group_by(age, favorite) |>
  summarize(count = n(), .groups = 'drop')

# creates proportion, which is the percentage of favorite in age 
coffee_survey3 <- data_summary |>
  group_by(age)  |>
  mutate(proportion = count / sum(count, na.rm = TRUE))

# makes graph
ggplot(coffee_survey3, 
       aes(x = favorite, y = proportion, fill = favorite)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") + 
  facet_wrap(~ age) +
    
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = scales::percent) +
  labs(
    x = "Favorite Way to Drink Coffee",
    y = "Percentage",
    title = "Favorite Ways to Drink Coffee Across Different Age Groups",
  )+
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_blank(),
  )

title: Cheese
text:
Data Source:

library(tidytuesdayR)
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)

# imports data from tidytuesday
tuesdata <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2024, week = 23)

# renames data
cheeses <- tuesdata$cheeses

# removes "mg/100g" from end of calcium_content
cheeses$calcium_content <- str_sub(cheeses$calcium_content, end = -8)

# turns calcium_content from a string into a number
cheeses$calcium_content <- as.numeric(cheeses$calcium_content)

# creates a new data point if there is more than one animal in milk
cheeses_separated <- cheeses |>
  separate_rows(milk, sep = ", ") 

# takes NAs out of milk and calcium content
cleaned_cheeses <- cheeses_separated |>
  filter(!is.na(milk) & !is.na(calcium_content)) |>
  # creates ranges for calcium_content & assigns them appropriate labels
  mutate(calcium_range = cut(calcium_content,
                         breaks = c(0, 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000, 5000),
                         labels = c("0-50", "50-100", "100-200", "200-500", "500-1000", "1000-5000")
                         ))

# assigns each range to a color 
colors <- c("0-50" = "#CDC754",  
            "50-100" = "#80CD54",
            "100-200" = "#54CD8D",
            "200-500" = "#54C2CD",  
            "500-1000" = "#7588F4",
            "1000-5000" = "#2D34A7") 

# makes plot
ggplot(cleaned_cheeses, aes(x = milk, y = color, fill = calcium_range)) +
  geom_tile() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = colors) +
  labs(
    x = "Type of Milk",
    y = "Color",
    title = "Calcium Content by Type of Milk and Cheese Color",
    fill = "Calcium Content (mg/100g)"
  )
